elements.content: Iron­(III) ions play a vital role in living biological systems, while organic pollutants including pesticides and antibiotics pose a great threat to the ecological environment. Effective detection for these species is crucial for human health and environmental protection. In this work, we designed and synthesized a new amino-decorated bridging ligand H2APDA and employed it to react with the environmentally friendly Mg­(II) ions to construct a novel magnesium luminescent metal–organic framework (Mg-LMOF), namely [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]·5DMA·5H2O (Mg-APDA). The as-synthesized Mg-LMOF is a three-dimensional framework with one-dimensional hexagonal channels. These microporous channels are decorated with Lewis-base amino sites and uncoordinated O atoms, which facilitate the Mg-APDA to anchor and recognize various analytes. Mg-APDA can be used as a multiresponsive luminescent sensor to detect Fe­(III) ions, pesticides, and antibiotics effectively. To the best of our knowledge, this work represents the first amino-decorated Mg-LMOF as an efficient fluorescent sensor for detecting metal ions, pesticides, and antibiotics simultaneously.
elements.clean_text: Iron(III) ions play a vital role in living biological systems, while organic pollutants including pesticides and antibiotics pose a great threat to the ecological environment. Effective detection for these species is crucial for human health and environmental protection. In this work, we designed and synthesized a new amino-decorated bridging ligand H2APDA and employed it to react with the environmentally friendly Mg(II) ions to construct a novel magnesium luminescent metal-organic framework (Mg-LMOF), namely [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (Mg-APDA). The as-synthesized Mg-LMOF is a three-dimensional framework with one-dimensional hexagonal channels. These microporous channels are decorated with Lewis-base amino sites and uncoordinated O atoms, which facilitate the Mg-APDA to anchor and recognize various analytes. Mg-APDA can be used as a multiresponsive luminescent sensor to detect Fe(III) ions, pesticides, and antibiotics effectively. To the best of our knowledge, this work represents the first amino-decorated Mg-LMOF as an efficient fluorescent sensor for detecting metal ions, pesticides, and antibiotics simultaneously.

elements.content:
A novel amino-functionalized Mg-LMOF exhibits multiresponsive fluorescence sensing behavior for Fe­(III) ions, pesticides, and antibiotics with high selectivity and sensitivity.

Introduction

Iron­(III) ions exist widely in living organisms and play a significant role in many biochemical processes such as oxygen transport, hemoglobin formation, cell metabolism, and DNA replication. Either their deficiency or excess may induce serious metabolism disorder diseases. Thus, the selective and sensitive detection of Fe­(III) ions over other metal ions is of great significance. On the other hand, pesticides and antibiotics are used extensively in agriculture and aquaculture to prevent and resist the external aggression. However, in recent decades, the abuse of pesticides and antibiotics has led to high levels of residue in the bodies of both plants and animals, and then these residual pesticides and antibiotics can be delivered to humans through the food chain. This no doubt poses a serious threat to the ecological environment and human health, owing to their intrinsic high toxicity and nondegradability. Currently, the traditional detection methods for organic pollutants such as ion mobility spectrometry (IMS), high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) are complicated and time-consuming. Therefore, the rapid and efficient detection methods/technologies for such specific environmental contaminants are urgently required, but challenging.
elements.clean_text:
A novel amino-functionalized Mg-LMOF exhibits multiresponsive fluorescence sensing behavior for Fe(III) ions, pesticides, and antibiotics with high selectivity and sensitivity.

Introduction

Iron(III) ions exist widely in living organisms and play a significant role in many biochemical processes such as oxygen transport, hemoglobin formation, cell metabolism, and DNA replication. Either their deficiency or excess may induce serious metabolism disorder diseases. Thus, the selective and sensitive detection of Fe(III) ions over other metal ions is of great significance. On the other hand, pesticides and antibiotics are used extensively in agriculture and aquaculture to prevent and resist the external aggression. However, in recent decades, the abuse of pesticides and antibiotics has led to high levels of residue in the bodies of both plants and animals, and then these residual pesticides and antibiotics can be delivered to humans through the food chain. This no doubt poses a serious threat to the ecological environment and human health, owing to their intrinsic high toxicity and nondegradability. Currently, the traditional detection methods for organic pollutants such as ion mobility spectrometry (IMS), high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) are complicated and time-consuming. Therefore, the rapid and efficient detection methods/technologies for such specific environmental contaminants are urgently required, but challenging.

elements.content: Recently, luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs) have attracted increasing attention as effective sensing materials due to their modifiable structures and topologies, prominent optical properties, and relatively long emission wavelength. Until now, a great deal of effort has been devoted to pursuing different kinds of LMOFs with excellent sensing performance, which are mostly based on the lanthanide or transition-metal ions. In contrast, the LMOFs constructed from alkaline earth metal ions have seldom been explored because of the inherent difficulties of their formation/crystallization processes and the unpredictable coordination geometries. As a matter of fact, alkaline earth-metal organic frameworks (AE-MOFs) have many unparalleled advantages for application such as low density, biofriendly, nontoxic, and low cost. More importantly, AE-MOFs could effectively avoid the secondary pollution caused by heavy metal ions when they are used as a fluorescent probe in some biological systems. Comparably, the reasonable design and synthesis of organic linkers with special binding sites and appropriate luminous performance are also crucial because the chemical affinity of the coordination spaces determines the selective capture of specific metal ions and the powerful luminophore decides the efficient recognition of the guest molecules. Many functional groups such as free pyridyl, imidazole, hydroxyl, and carboxyl groups have been immobilized on the pore surfaces of LMOFs to enhance the fluorescence sensing capability through various host–guest interactions. The amino group is a typical representative among the various electron-donating groups and can also bind to metal ions, hence it can be reasonably modified into the MOF structures. However, there are only a few reports on the LMOFs functionalized by amino groups up to now.
elements.clean_text: Recently, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have attracted increasing attention as effective sensing materials due to their modifiable structures and topologies, prominent optical properties, and relatively long emission wavelength. Until now, a great deal of effort has been devoted to pursuing different kinds of LMOFs with excellent sensing performance, which are mostly based on the lanthanide or transition-metal ions. In contrast, the LMOFs constructed from alkaline earth metal ions have seldom been explored because of the inherent difficulties of their formation/crystallization processes and the unpredictable coordination geometries. As a matter of fact, alkaline earth-metal organic frameworks (AE-MOFs) have many unparalleled advantages for application such as low density, biofriendly, nontoxic, and low cost. More importantly, AE-MOFs could effectively avoid the secondary pollution caused by heavy metal ions when they are used as a fluorescent probe in some biological systems. Comparably, the reasonable design and synthesis of organic linkers with special binding sites and appropriate luminous performance are also crucial because the chemical affinity of the coordination spaces determines the selective capture of specific metal ions and the powerful luminophore decides the efficient recognition of the guest molecules. Many functional groups such as free pyridyl, imidazole, hydroxyl, and carboxyl groups have been immobilized on the pore surfaces of LMOFs to enhance the fluorescence sensing capability through various host-guest interactions. The amino group is a typical representative among the various electron-donating groups and can also bind to metal ions, hence it can be reasonably modified into the MOF structures. However, there are only a few reports on the LMOFs functionalized by amino groups up to now.

elements.content: Considering the above-mentioned, we designed and synthesized a new amino-decorated bridging ligand 4,4′-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (H2APDA) () and employed it to react with the environmentally friendly Mg­(II) ions to fabricate a novel alkaline earth LMOF namely [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]·5DMA·5H2O (Mg-APDA). The as-synthesized Mg-LMOF is a three-dimensional (3D) framework with one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites. It could be employed as a highly selective fluorescent probe for Fe­(III) ions with excellent anti-interference performance. Most strikingly, Mg-APDA can also be applied to efficiently detect environmental pollutants including pesticide and antibiotics, which makes it exhibit a multiresponsive fluorescence sensing behavior. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of Mg-LMOF as an effective fluorescent sensor for detecting pesticide and antibiotics.
elements.clean_text: Considering the above-mentioned, we designed and synthesized a new amino-decorated bridging ligand 4,4'-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2APDA) () and employed it to react with the environmentally friendly Mg(II) ions to fabricate a novel alkaline earth LMOF namely [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (Mg-APDA). The as-synthesized Mg-LMOF is a three-dimensional (3D) framework with one-dimensional (1D) hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites. It could be employed as a highly selective fluorescent probe for Fe(III) ions with excellent anti-interference performance. Most strikingly, Mg-APDA can also be applied to efficiently detect environmental pollutants including pesticide and antibiotics, which makes it exhibit a multiresponsive fluorescence sensing behavior. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of Mg-LMOF as an effective fluorescent sensor for detecting pesticide and antibiotics.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were of AR grade and used directly without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker AV-400 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were measured on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected as KBr pellets in the region of 4000–400 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Philips X’Pert PRO automated diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a Pyris1 thermogravimetric analyzer with a ramp rate of 10 °C per minute from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. Luminescence spectra were collected on a FLS920 spectrophotometer. The determinations of luminescence lifetimes and quantum yield were performed on an Edinburgh FL980 fluorescence spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were of AR grade and used directly without further purification. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker AV-400 spectrometer. Elemental analyses were measured on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. UV-vis absorption spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected as KBr pellets in the region of 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Philips X'Pert PRO automated diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a Pyris1 thermogravimetric analyzer with a ramp rate of 10 °C per minute from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. Luminescence spectra were collected on a FLS920 spectrophotometer. The determinations of luminescence lifetimes and quantum yield were performed on an Edinburgh FL980 fluorescence spectrometer.

elements.content:
The synthetic procedures of the ligand, 4,4′-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (H2APDA), are described in detail in Section 1 of the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [Mg<sub>2</sub>(APDA)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·5DMA·5H<sub>2</sub>O (Mg-APDA)

A mixture of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.04 mmol) and H2APDA (0.01 mmol) was dissolved in DMA/ethanol/H2O mixed solvent (2.2 mL, v/v/v: 2/0.1/0.1), and then the solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless crystals of Mg-APDA were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and then dried in air (yield: 58%, based on H2APDA). Anal. calcd (%): C, 53.88; H, 6.63; N, 9.75. Found (%): C, 53.82; H, 6.67; N, 9.78. IR (KBr, cm–1) (Figure S1): 3484 (w), 3394 (w), 1622 (s), 1549 (m), 1469 (w), 1406 (s), 1315 (w), 1184 (w), 1014 (m), 793 (m), 718 (w), 675 (w), 594 (w), 498 (w).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand (H2APDA)

The synthetic procedures of the ligand, 4,4'-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2APDA), are described in detail in Section 1 of the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (Mg-APDA)

A mixture of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.04 mmol) and H2APDA (0.01 mmol) was dissolved in DMA/ethanol/H2O mixed solvent (2.2 mL, v/v/v: 2/0.1/0.1), and then the solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless crystals of Mg-APDA were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and then dried in air (yield: 58%, based on H2APDA). Anal. calcd (%): C, 53.88; H, 6.63; N, 9.75. Found (%): C, 53.82; H, 6.67; N, 9.78. IR (KBr, cm-1) (Figure S1): 3484 (w), 3394 (w), 1622 (s), 1549 (m), 1469 (w), 1406 (s), 1315 (w), 1184 (w), 1014 (m), 793 (m), 718 (w), 675 (w), 594 (w), 498 (w).

elements.content: In a typical experimental procedure, 2.5 mg of fine powder of Mg-APDA was dispersed in 2.5 mL of fresh DMF to form a stable suspension after ultrasonic treatment for a few minutes. All fluorescence titration experiments were performed by gradually adding 1 mM DMF solution of different analytes [Fe­(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)]. The obtained mixture was placed in a 1 cm width quartz cell for the test. Fluorescence detections were performed at the emission wavelength ranging from 360 to 550 nm with an excitation wavelength (λex) at 351 nm at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

In a typical experimental procedure, 2.5 mg of fine powder of Mg-APDA was dispersed in 2.5 mL of fresh DMF to form a stable suspension after ultrasonic treatment for a few minutes. All fluorescence titration experiments were performed by gradually adding 1 mM DMF solution of different analytes [Fe(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)]. The obtained mixture was placed in a 1 cm width quartz cell for the test. Fluorescence detections were performed at the emission wavelength ranging from 360 to 550 nm with an excitation wavelength (λex) at 351 nm at room temperature.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data for Mg-APDA were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD based diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 100 K. The structure of Mg-APDA was solved via direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL-2014 program. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. The PLATON/SQUEEZE routine was used to eliminate the diffraction contribution of the disordered guest molecules. The crystal data and structure refinement information on Mg-APDA are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography Study

Single-crystal X-ray data for Mg-APDA were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD based diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 100 K. The structure of Mg-APDA was solved via direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL-2014 program. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. The PLATON/SQUEEZE routine was used to eliminate the diffraction contribution of the disordered guest molecules. The crystal data and structure refinement information on Mg-APDA are summarized in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2.

elements.content: Structural analysis reveals that Mg-APDA crystallizes in the triclinic with P-1 space group and contains two Mg­(II) atoms, two APDA ligands, three coordinated water molecules, five free DMA molecules, and five uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Mg(1) atom is six-coordinated by three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O8) coming from three different ligands, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N1) from another ligand, and two oxygen atoms (O5, O7) from two coordinated water molecules. The Mg(2) atom forms a more regular octahedral geometry, in which three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, O9, O11) and one pyridine nitrogen atom (N3) constitute the equatorial plane, while the axial sites are occupied by two coordinated water molecules. The two Mg atoms are linked by two bridging COO– groups and one μ-H2O molecule to form a dinuclear unit of [Mg2(COO)2(μ-H2O)] acting as the SBU for Mg-APDA. The bond lengths of Mg–O vary from 2.016(3)–2.133(3) Å, and the lengths of two Mg–N bonds are 2.168(4) and 2.239(4) Å, respectively. From the point of bridging ligands, each APDA ligand is connected with four Mg atoms utilizing its pyridine nitrogen atom and two carboxylate groups. Each SBU is interconnected to 12 neighboring SBUs by the APDA linkers, resulting in a 3D host framework with 1D hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites (b,c). Each channel has an approximate diameter of 8.0 Å along the a-axis. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON, is 62.8% after removing all of the guest molecules from the channels. Taking the dinuclear SBU as a 6-connected node and the APDA ligand as a 3-connected node, Mg-APDA exhibits a topology (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (Mg-APDA)

Structural analysis reveals that Mg-APDA crystallizes in the triclinic with P-1 space group and contains two Mg(II) atoms, two APDA ligands, three coordinated water molecules, five free DMA molecules, and five uncoordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Mg(1) atom is six-coordinated by three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O2, O4, O8) coming from three different ligands, one pyridine nitrogen atom (N1) from another ligand, and two oxygen atoms (O5, O7) from two coordinated water molecules. The Mg(2) atom forms a more regular octahedral geometry, in which three carboxyl oxygen atoms (O1, O9, O11) and one pyridine nitrogen atom (N3) constitute the equatorial plane, while the axial sites are occupied by two coordinated water molecules. The two Mg atoms are linked by two bridging COO- groups and one μ-H2O molecule to form a dinuclear unit of [Mg2(COO)2(μ-H2O)] acting as the SBU for Mg-APDA. The bond lengths of Mg-O vary from 2.016(3)-2.133(3) Å, and the lengths of two Mg-N bonds are 2.168(4) and 2.239(4) Å, respectively. From the point of bridging ligands, each APDA ligand is connected with four Mg atoms utilizing its pyridine nitrogen atom and two carboxylate groups. Each SBU is interconnected to 12 neighboring SBUs by the APDA linkers, resulting in a 3D host framework with 1D hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites (b,c). Each channel has an approximate diameter of 8.0 Å along the a-axis. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON, is 62.8% after removing all of the guest molecules from the channels. Taking the dinuclear SBU as a 6-connected node and the APDA ligand as a 3-connected node, Mg-APDA exhibits a topology (d).

elements.content: (a) The coordination environment of Mg­(II) atoms and the bonding mode of APDA in Mg-APDA. (b) Perspective view of the 3D framework along the a-axis. (c) 1D microporous channel in Mg-APDA. (d) Topology of Mg-APDA.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environment of Mg(II) atoms and the bonding mode of APDA in Mg-APDA. (b) Perspective view of the 3D framework along the a-axis. (c) 1D microporous channel in Mg-APDA. (d) Topology of Mg-APDA.

elements.content: The structural diversity of PDA-based MOFs is mainly dependent upon the rich coordination modes of the 4,4′-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (H2PDA) ligand and the diverse metal selections. Sun et al. reported four new MOFs based on the H2PDA ligand and four different kinds of transition metals (Zn, Cd, Co, Mn). The PDA ligand showed variable coordination modes with different metal ions. The metal centers (Zn, Cd, Co, Mn) in these four MOF structures were five-, seven-, six-, and six-coordinated, respectively, and the final crystallographic structures varied from 2D networks to 3D frameworks. Different from these above coordination modes of PDA ligand, the APDA ligand displays a novel coordination mode in the structure of Mg-APDA, and the two Mg­(II) atoms are all six-coordinated (a). The dinuclear unit is interconnected by the APDA linkers to form a 3D host framework. This indicates that the multiple coordination modes of organic ligands and the diversity of metal ions have significant influences on the crystal structures of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The structural diversity of PDA-based MOFs is mainly dependent upon the rich coordination modes of the 4,4'-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2PDA) ligand and the diverse metal selections. Sun et al. reported four new MOFs based on the H2PDA ligand and four different kinds of transition metals (Zn, Cd, Co, Mn). The PDA ligand showed variable coordination modes with different metal ions. The metal centers (Zn, Cd, Co, Mn) in these four MOF structures were five-, seven-, six-, and six-coordinated, respectively, and the final crystallographic structures varied from 2D networks to 3D frameworks. Different from these above coordination modes of PDA ligand, the APDA ligand displays a novel coordination mode in the structure of Mg-APDA, and the two Mg(II) atoms are all six-coordinated (a). The dinuclear unit is interconnected by the APDA linkers to form a 3D host framework. This indicates that the multiple coordination modes of organic ligands and the diversity of metal ions have significant influences on the crystal structures of MOFs.

elements.content: To get the information on the stability of Mg-APDA, TGA was conducted from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S2). The TGA curve shows a weight loss of 40.87% from 30 to 170 °C, which corresponds to the loss of free DMA and water molecules (calcd 40.66%), and the further weight loss corresponds to the slow decomposition of the framework. Besides, PXRD analysis was performed to determine the phase purity of Mg-APDA. As represented in Figure S3, the diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized Mg-APDA are highly consistent with the simulated PXRD patterns, indicative of the excellent phase purity. To determine the effect of fluorescence detections on the structural stability of the Mg-APDA framework, the samples after immersed in the DMF solution (1.0 mM) with different analytes (Fe­(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)) for 6 h were also analyzed by PXRD, as shown in Figure S4. It is seen that there is no significant difference in the PXRD patterns between the immersed sample and the original sample, which indicates that the basic Mg-APDA framework remains unchanged.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and PXRD Measurements

To get the information on the stability of Mg-APDA, TGA was conducted from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S2). The TGA curve shows a weight loss of 40.87% from 30 to 170 °C, which corresponds to the loss of free DMA and water molecules (calcd 40.66%), and the further weight loss corresponds to the slow decomposition of the framework. Besides, PXRD analysis was performed to determine the phase purity of Mg-APDA. As represented in Figure S3, the diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized Mg-APDA are highly consistent with the simulated PXRD patterns, indicative of the excellent phase purity. To determine the effect of fluorescence detections on the structural stability of the Mg-APDA framework, the samples after immersed in the DMF solution (1.0 mM) with different analytes (Fe(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)) for 6 h were also analyzed by PXRD, as shown in Figure S4. It is seen that there is no significant difference in the PXRD patterns between the immersed sample and the original sample, which indicates that the basic Mg-APDA framework remains unchanged.

elements.content: The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand and Mg-APDA were conducted at ambient temperature. As illustrated in Figure S5, the free ligand H2APDA shows a fluorescent emission band at 365 nm (λex = 339 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transition between the π-bonding orbital and π*-antibonding orbital. For comparison, Mg-APDA exhibits intense blue light emission at 384 nm (λex = 351 nm) with a 70.46% quantum yield. Compared to the free ligand, a significant red-shifted emission phenomenon is observed on Mg-APDA, and its fluorescent intensity dramatically increases. On account of the unique d0 electron configuration of Mg­(II) ions, it can be concluded that the fluorescence of Mg-APDA should originate from the APDA-centered emission.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand and Mg-APDA were conducted at ambient temperature. As illustrated in Figure S5, the free ligand H2APDA shows a fluorescent emission band at 365 nm (λex = 339 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transition between the π-bonding orbital and π*-antibonding orbital. For comparison, Mg-APDA exhibits intense blue light emission at 384 nm (λex = 351 nm) with a 70.46% quantum yield. Compared to the free ligand, a significant red-shifted emission phenomenon is observed on Mg-APDA, and its fluorescent intensity dramatically increases. On account of the unique d0 electron configuration of Mg(II) ions, it can be concluded that the fluorescence of Mg-APDA should originate from the APDA-centered emission.

elements.content: Considering that the N atoms of amino groups and uncoordinated O atoms of carboxyl groups can bind to metal ions, the application of Mg-APDA as a potential fluorescent sensor for metal ions was explored. Before the luminescence sensing study, we first checked the fluorescent intensity of Mg-APDA in several common organic solvents. As depicted in Figure S6, the luminescent intensity of Mg-APDA is largely dependent on the solvent molecules, and it exhibits the strongest fluorescence emission in the suspension of DMF. Therefore, DMF was chosen as the dispersed solvent for luminescence sensing applications.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Metal Ions

Considering that the N atoms of amino groups and uncoordinated O atoms of carboxyl groups can bind to metal ions, the application of Mg-APDA as a potential fluorescent sensor for metal ions was explored. Before the luminescence sensing study, we first checked the fluorescent intensity of Mg-APDA in several common organic solvents. As depicted in Figure S6, the luminescent intensity of Mg-APDA is largely dependent on the solvent molecules, and it exhibits the strongest fluorescence emission in the suspension of DMF. Therefore, DMF was chosen as the dispersed solvent for luminescence sensing applications.

elements.content: To investigate the potential of Mg-APDA for sensing trace quantities of metal ions, 2.5 mg finely grounded samples were evenly dispersed in 2.5 mL DMF solutions containing M­(NO3)× (1 mM, M = Ni2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Mn2+, Na+, Cd2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Cr3+, K+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Co2+, and Fe3+) to form steady turbid suspensions for fluorescence measurements. Notably, Fe3+ ions exhibit a nearly complete quenching effect on the luminescence of Mg-APDA, while the other metal ions have slight or moderate quenching effects on the fluorescence emission, indicating the extremely high selectivity toward Fe3+ ions ( and S7). In order to explore the sensing sensitivity of Mg-APDA toward Fe3+ ions, quantitative fluorescence titration experiments were performed. As revealed in a, the fluorescent intensity of Mg-APDA decreases gradually with increasing the concentration of Fe3+ ions. The changes of fluorescent intensity were recorded based on the emission at 385 nm and the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M]) was applied to quantitatively explain the fluorescence quenching efficiency, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after addition of the analyte, respectively, K sv is the quenching effect coefficient (M–1), and [M] is the molar concentration of the analyte. As represented in b, the SV plot for Fe3+ ions is almost linear at low concentration range and then deviates from linearity to exponential increase at higher concentration, which can be explained by self-absorption or an energy-transfer process. According to the experimental data, the K sv value is calculated to be 2.06 × 104 M–1, which reveals a high quenching efficiency of Fe3+ ions on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA. Based on the K sv value and the standard deviation (δ) for three repeated fluorescent measurements of blank solutions, the limit of detection (LOD) for Fe3+ ions is estimated to be 152 ppb by the ratio of 3δ/K sv, which is better than the reported Mg­(II)-based LMOFs using for the Fe3+ ions detection. The detection limit is also comparable to or better than some recently reported MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Fe3+ ions (Table S3). As far as we know, Mg-APDA is the first amino-decorated Mg-LMOF that can be employed as a potential effective fluorescent sensor for detecting metal ions.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the potential of Mg-APDA for sensing trace quantities of metal ions, 2.5 mg finely grounded samples were evenly dispersed in 2.5 mL DMF solutions containing M(NO3)× (1 mM, M = Ni2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Mn2+, Na+, Cd2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Ag+, Cr3+, K+, Zn2+, Cu2+, Co2+, and Fe3+) to form steady turbid suspensions for fluorescence measurements. Notably, Fe3+ ions exhibit a nearly complete quenching effect on the luminescence of Mg-APDA, while the other metal ions have slight or moderate quenching effects on the fluorescence emission, indicating the extremely high selectivity toward Fe3+ ions ( and S7). In order to explore the sensing sensitivity of Mg-APDA toward Fe3+ ions, quantitative fluorescence titration experiments were performed. As revealed in a, the fluorescent intensity of Mg-APDA decreases gradually with increasing the concentration of Fe3+ ions. The changes of fluorescent intensity were recorded based on the emission at 385 nm and the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M]) was applied to quantitatively explain the fluorescence quenching efficiency, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after addition of the analyte, respectively, K sv is the quenching effect coefficient (M-1), and [M] is the molar concentration of the analyte. As represented in b, the SV plot for Fe3+ ions is almost linear at low concentration range and then deviates from linearity to exponential increase at higher concentration, which can be explained by self-absorption or an energy-transfer process. According to the experimental data, the K sv value is calculated to be 2.06 × 104 M-1, which reveals a high quenching efficiency of Fe3+ ions on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA. Based on the K sv value and the standard deviation (δ) for three repeated fluorescent measurements of blank solutions, the limit of detection (LOD) for Fe3+ ions is estimated to be 152 ppb by the ratio of 3δ/K sv, which is better than the reported Mg(II)-based LMOFs using for the Fe3+ ions detection. The detection limit is also comparable to or better than some recently reported MOF fluorescent sensors for detecting Fe3+ ions (Table S3). As far as we know, Mg-APDA is the first amino-decorated Mg-LMOF that can be employed as a potential effective fluorescent sensor for detecting metal ions.

elements.content: It needs to be noted that many metal ions may coexist in some practical biological and environmental systems. To check the detection selectivity for Fe3+ ions over other interfering metal ions, the competitive experiments were performed. It can be seen that the luminescence quenching response of MOF suspensions induced by Fe3+ ions is almost not influenced by the interfering metal ions, indicating that Mg-APDA can effectively detect Fe3+ ions even in the presence of other metal ions (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text: It needs to be noted that many metal ions may coexist in some practical biological and environmental systems. To check the detection selectivity for Fe3+ ions over other interfering metal ions, the competitive experiments were performed. It can be seen that the luminescence quenching response of MOF suspensions induced by Fe3+ ions is almost not influenced by the interfering metal ions, indicating that Mg-APDA can effectively detect Fe3+ ions even in the presence of other metal ions (Figure S8).

elements.content: Antibiotics are widely used as additives in human and animal medicines and now have been considered as a class of serious organic pollutants. Thus, efficient detection of antibiotics is of paramount importance for environmental protection and public security. In light of the intense photoluminescence and high porosity of Mg-APDA, we tried to explore its application in sensing a trace amount of antibiotics. A total of nine commonly used antibiotics from five classes, NFs (nitrofurazone, NZF; nitrofurantoin, NFT), NMs (metronidazole, MDZ; dimetridazole, DTZ), sulfonamides (sulfadiazine, SDZ; sulfamethazine, SMZ), chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP; thiamphenicol, THI), and β-lactams (penicillin, PCL) were investigated (Scheme S2). The finely grounded samples of Mg-APDA (2.5 mg) were dispersed in 2.5 mL of DMF solution containing these antibiotics (0.10 mM), and the luminescence sensing performance was recorded and compared, as shown in and S11. Evidently, NZF and NFT give rise to the highest quenching efficiencies of 97.2 and 97.6%, calculated by (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100%, while the other antibiotics show negligible effect on the luminescent intensity with the exception of NMs, which weaken the fluorescence emission to some extent. This phenomenon indicates that Mg-APDA can be regarded as a promising MOF-based fluorescent probe for highly selective detection toward NFs. To further explore the quenching effect of NFs on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA, the similar fluorescence titration experiments were conducted, and the relationship between luminescence quenching efficiency and NZF/NFT concentration can also be quantitatively described by the Stern–Volmer equation. As indicated in , the SV plots for NZF and NFT exhibit a good linear correlation at low concentrations and then deviate from linearity and bend upward at higher concentrations. Based on the experimental data, the K sv values are calculated as 9.00 × 104 M–1 for NZF and 8.82 × 104 M–1 for NFT. The detection limits of Mg-APDA toward NZF and NFT are calculated to be 108 and 126 ppb, respectively, which is comparable to those of the well-designed novel MOFs for the sensing of NZF/NFT (Table S4). This work represents the first example of Mg-MOF-based luminescent sensors for the highly efficient detection of antibiotics.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Antibiotics

Antibiotics are widely used as additives in human and animal medicines and now have been considered as a class of serious organic pollutants. Thus, efficient detection of antibiotics is of paramount importance for environmental protection and public security. In light of the intense photoluminescence and high porosity of Mg-APDA, we tried to explore its application in sensing a trace amount of antibiotics. A total of nine commonly used antibiotics from five classes, NFs (nitrofurazone, NZF; nitrofurantoin, NFT), NMs (metronidazole, MDZ; dimetridazole, DTZ), sulfonamides (sulfadiazine, SDZ; sulfamethazine, SMZ), chloramphenicols (chloramphenicol, CAP; thiamphenicol, THI), and β-lactams (penicillin, PCL) were investigated (Scheme S2). The finely grounded samples of Mg-APDA (2.5 mg) were dispersed in 2.5 mL of DMF solution containing these antibiotics (0.10 mM), and the luminescence sensing performance was recorded and compared, as shown in  and S11. Evidently, NZF and NFT give rise to the highest quenching efficiencies of 97.2 and 97.6%, calculated by (I 0 - I)/I 0 × 100%, while the other antibiotics show negligible effect on the luminescent intensity with the exception of NMs, which weaken the fluorescence emission to some extent. This phenomenon indicates that Mg-APDA can be regarded as a promising MOF-based fluorescent probe for highly selective detection toward NFs. To further explore the quenching effect of NFs on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA, the similar fluorescence titration experiments were conducted, and the relationship between luminescence quenching efficiency and NZF/NFT concentration can also be quantitatively described by the Stern-Volmer equation. As indicated in , the SV plots for NZF and NFT exhibit a good linear correlation at low concentrations and then deviate from linearity and bend upward at higher concentrations. Based on the experimental data, the K sv values are calculated as 9.00 × 104 M-1 for NZF and 8.82 × 104 M-1 for NFT. The detection limits of Mg-APDA toward NZF and NFT are calculated to be 108 and 126 ppb, respectively, which is comparable to those of the well-designed novel MOFs for the sensing of NZF/NFT (Table S4). This work represents the first example of Mg-MOF-based luminescent sensors for the highly efficient detection of antibiotics.

elements.content: Fluorescence spectra of Mg-APDA dispersed in DMF suspension upon incremental addition of NZF (a) and NFT (c) Fluorescence emission quenching linearity relationships at low concentrations of NZF (b) and NFT (d). SV plots of Mg-APDA upon incremental addition of each antibiotic (inset).
elements.clean_text: 5  Fluorescence spectra of Mg-APDA dispersed in DMF suspension upon incremental addition of NZF (a) and NFT (c) Fluorescence emission quenching linearity relationships at low concentrations of NZF (b) and NFT (d). SV plots of Mg-APDA upon incremental addition of each antibiotic (inset).

elements.content: The highly quenching efficiency of Mg-APDA toward NFs promotes us to investigate the detection selectivity for NFs with the existence of other potential interfering antibiotics. As illustrated in a, upon introducing NZF into the mixture of Mg-APDA and other antibiotics, the fluorescence was significantly quenched, suggesting the high selectivity of Mg-APDA for the detection of NFs even in the presence of a high concentration of other antibiotics. Furthermore, the recyclable performance of Mg-APDA for NZF detection was also investigated. After fluorescence detection, the solid compound was collected from the mixture through centrifugation and then washed several times with fresh DMF. Significantly, the sample could be regenerated and reused for five cycles, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency was essentially retained, demonstrating its good structural stability and recyclability for the antibiotic detection applications (b).
elements.clean_text: The highly quenching efficiency of Mg-APDA toward NFs promotes us to investigate the detection selectivity for NFs with the existence of other potential interfering antibiotics. As illustrated in a, upon introducing NZF into the mixture of Mg-APDA and other antibiotics, the fluorescence was significantly quenched, suggesting the high selectivity of Mg-APDA for the detection of NFs even in the presence of a high concentration of other antibiotics. Furthermore, the recyclable performance of Mg-APDA for NZF detection was also investigated. After fluorescence detection, the solid compound was collected from the mixture through centrifugation and then washed several times with fresh DMF. Significantly, the sample could be regenerated and reused for five cycles, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency was essentially retained, demonstrating its good structural stability and recyclability for the antibiotic detection applications (b).

elements.content: (a) Fluorescent response of Mg-APDA toward the competing antibiotics (0.100 mM) or a mixture of competing antibiotics (0.100 mM) and NZF (0.057 mM). (b) Reusability of Mg-APDA implemented with the DMF solution of NZF (0.060 mM).
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Fluorescent response of Mg-APDA toward the competing antibiotics (0.100 mM) or a mixture of competing antibiotics (0.100 mM) and NZF (0.057 mM). (b) Reusability of Mg-APDA implemented with the DMF solution of NZF (0.060 mM).

elements.content: Pesticides have been used extensively for agriculture production, but the abuse of them has led to the intense public concern about food safety and health protection. Therefore, the rapid and sensitive detection toward pesticides is of great importance. The remarkable fluorescence sensing performance of Mg-APDA inspired us to investigate its applications toward pesticides detection. In this work, five frequently used pesticides, including 2,4-dichlorophenol, carbaryl, atrazine, chlorpyrifos, and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN), were investigated (Scheme S3). and S14 show the effects of the above pesticides (0.1 mM) on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA. It can be seen that the fluorescence emission is most prominently quenched by DCN, while the other pesticides have no obvious effects on the luminescent intensity, which indicates the high sensitivity of Mg-APDA toward DCN in DMF solution. Moreover, the competition experiments revealed that the presence of other pesticides did not affect the luminescence quenching response induced by DCN, further confirming that Mg-APDA may act as a promising selective fluorescent sensor for DCN (a). Remarkably, the luminescence of Mg-APDA can be easily switched on through centrifugation of the dispersion after the fluorescence quenching experiment and subsequent washing several times with fresh DMF. As represented in b, the fluorescent intensity and quenching efficiency of Mg-APDA were basically unchanged after five recycling experiments. All of the results suggest that Mg-APDA possesses good anti-interference abilities and excellent recyclability for the pesticide sensing applications.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Pesticides

Pesticides have been used extensively for agriculture production, but the abuse of them has led to the intense public concern about food safety and health protection. Therefore, the rapid and sensitive detection toward pesticides is of great importance. The remarkable fluorescence sensing performance of Mg-APDA inspired us to investigate its applications toward pesticides detection. In this work, five frequently used pesticides, including 2,4-dichlorophenol, carbaryl, atrazine, chlorpyrifos, and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN), were investigated (Scheme S3).  and S14 show the effects of the above pesticides (0.1 mM) on the fluorescence emission of Mg-APDA. It can be seen that the fluorescence emission is most prominently quenched by DCN, while the other pesticides have no obvious effects on the luminescent intensity, which indicates the high sensitivity of Mg-APDA toward DCN in DMF solution. Moreover, the competition experiments revealed that the presence of other pesticides did not affect the luminescence quenching response induced by DCN, further confirming that Mg-APDA may act as a promising selective fluorescent sensor for DCN (a). Remarkably, the luminescence of Mg-APDA can be easily switched on through centrifugation of the dispersion after the fluorescence quenching experiment and subsequent washing several times with fresh DMF. As represented in b, the fluorescent intensity and quenching efficiency of Mg-APDA were basically unchanged after five recycling experiments. All of the results suggest that Mg-APDA possesses good anti-interference abilities and excellent recyclability for the pesticide sensing applications.

elements.content: To further understand the fluorescence emissive response of Mg-APDA toward DCN, fluorescence titration experiments were performed, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency was presented by the Stern–Volmer equation. From the SV plot in b, the calculated K sv value is 7.50 × 104 M–1, and the obtained detection limit is 150 ppb by the ratio of 3δ/K sv, which is comparable to the reported fluorescent sensor using for DCN detection. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported Mg-MOF-based fluorescence sensing material that can efficiently detect trace amounts of pesticides.
elements.clean_text: To further understand the fluorescence emissive response of Mg-APDA toward DCN, fluorescence titration experiments were performed, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency was presented by the Stern-Volmer equation. From the SV plot in b, the calculated K sv value is 7.50 × 104 M-1, and the obtained detection limit is 150 ppb by the ratio of 3δ/K sv, which is comparable to the reported fluorescent sensor using for DCN detection. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported Mg-MOF-based fluorescence sensing material that can efficiently detect trace amounts of pesticides.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of Mg-APDA dispersed in DMF suspension upon incremental addition of DCN. (b) Fluorescence emission quenching linearity relationship at low concentration of DCN. SV plot of Mg-APDA upon incremental addition of DCN (inset).
elements.clean_text: 9  (a) Fluorescence spectra of Mg-APDA dispersed in DMF suspension upon incremental addition of DCN. (b) Fluorescence emission quenching linearity relationship at low concentration of DCN. SV plot of Mg-APDA upon incremental addition of DCN (inset).

elements.content: To better understand the highly selective fluorescence quenching effect of Mg-APDA toward Fe­(III) ions, NFs and DCN, the fluorescent quenching mechanism was investigated systematically. First, the PXRD analysis for the samples after immersed in the DMF solution with various analytes (Figure S4) indicates that the fluorescence quenching is not generated from the collapse of Mg-APDA framework. Second, the luminescence lifetime (τ) of Mg-APDA (Figure S9) is almost unchanged before and after the addition of Fe­(III) ions, suggesting that there is no coordination interactions between the metal ions and the framework structure. Third, the effective spectral overlap is observed between the UV–vis absorption spectrum of Fe­(III) ions and the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, while the other metal ions show almost no spectral overlap (Figure S10). Many researches have also revealed that Fe­(III) ions possess strong UV–vis absorption from 320 to 400 nm, which has a wide overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA. Thus, the energy-transfer mechanism can be used to explain the luminescence quenching effect induced by Fe­(III) ions. As for antibiotics and pesticides, photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process is a well-established quenching mechanism, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency is controlled by the donor–acceptor electron-transfer process. Undoubtedly, the lower unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of an analyte, the more effective fluorescence quenching effect will be presented. As revealed in Figures S12 and S15 and Tables S5–S6, the calculated LUMO energies are in accordance with the maximum quenching efficiencies for NFs and DCN, but the order of quenching efficiency does not exhibit the complete consistency with the LUMO energies of the other tested antibiotics and pesticides. In addition, the nonlinear trend of the SV plots for NFs and DCN indeed implies that the PET process is not the only mechanism responsible for the observed fluorescence quenching phenomenon in these systems. The resonance energy-transfer (RET) mechanism, containing energy transfer from the exited state of Mg-APDA to the analyte through nonradiative dipole–dipole interactions, can also contribute to the fluorescence quenching process. It is acknowledged that the higher the spectral overlap between the absorbance spectrum of the analyte and the emission spectrum of the framework structure, the greater possibility of energy transfer, and then resulting in the higher fluorescence quenching effect. As shown in Figures S13 and S16, the UV–vis absorption bands of NFs and DCN have the greatest overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, which further confirms the above explanation of fluorescence quenching effect. Therefore, the co-existence of electron-transfer and energy-transfer processes makes NFs and DCN exhibit higher luminescence quenching effects than other tested antibiotics and pesticides.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Luminescent Sensing

To better understand the highly selective fluorescence quenching effect of Mg-APDA toward Fe(III) ions, NFs and DCN, the fluorescent quenching mechanism was investigated systematically. First, the PXRD analysis for the samples after immersed in the DMF solution with various analytes (Figure S4) indicates that the fluorescence quenching is not generated from the collapse of Mg-APDA framework. Second, the luminescence lifetime (τ) of Mg-APDA (Figure S9) is almost unchanged before and after the addition of Fe(III) ions, suggesting that there is no coordination interactions between the metal ions and the framework structure. Third, the effective spectral overlap is observed between the UV-vis absorption spectrum of Fe(III) ions and the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, while the other metal ions show almost no spectral overlap (Figure S10). Many researches have also revealed that Fe(III) ions possess strong UV-vis absorption from 320 to 400 nm, which has a wide overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA. Thus, the energy-transfer mechanism can be used to explain the luminescence quenching effect induced by Fe(III) ions. As for antibiotics and pesticides, photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process is a well-established quenching mechanism, and the fluorescence quenching efficiency is controlled by the donor-acceptor electron-transfer process. Undoubtedly, the lower unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of an analyte, the more effective fluorescence quenching effect will be presented. As revealed in Figures S12 and S15 and Tables S5-S6, the calculated LUMO energies are in accordance with the maximum quenching efficiencies for NFs and DCN, but the order of quenching efficiency does not exhibit the complete consistency with the LUMO energies of the other tested antibiotics and pesticides. In addition, the nonlinear trend of the SV plots for NFs and DCN indeed implies that the PET process is not the only mechanism responsible for the observed fluorescence quenching phenomenon in these systems. The resonance energy-transfer (RET) mechanism, containing energy transfer from the exited state of Mg-APDA to the analyte through nonradiative dipole-dipole interactions, can also contribute to the fluorescence quenching process. It is acknowledged that the higher the spectral overlap between the absorbance spectrum of the analyte and the emission spectrum of the framework structure, the greater possibility of energy transfer, and then resulting in the higher fluorescence quenching effect. As shown in Figures S13 and S16, the UV-vis absorption bands of NFs and DCN have the greatest overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, which further confirms the above explanation of fluorescence quenching effect. Therefore, the co-existence of electron-transfer and energy-transfer processes makes NFs and DCN exhibit higher luminescence quenching effects than other tested antibiotics and pesticides.

elements.content: Regarding the effect of amino group on the luminescent detection performance, the amino group in organic luminescent compounds is a powerful electron-donating group, while both the paramagnetic high-spin Fe­(III) ions and nitroaromatics have strong electron-withdrawing ability. Thus, these electron-deficient compounds can be effectively recognized by the electron-rich LMOFs in the form of fluorescence quenching due to either electron-transfer or energy-transfer processes. The introduction of amino groups could increase the electron cloud density of Mg-APDA, thereby facilitating the electron-transfer or energy-transfer processes and then resulting in higher selectivity and sensitivity for luminescent detection. The improvements of luminescent detection performance by introducing amino group were also demonstrated in the literature.
elements.clean_text: Regarding the effect of amino group on the luminescent detection performance, the amino group in organic luminescent compounds is a powerful electron-donating group, while both the paramagnetic high-spin Fe(III) ions and nitroaromatics have strong electron-withdrawing ability. Thus, these electron-deficient compounds can be effectively recognized by the electron-rich LMOFs in the form of fluorescence quenching due to either electron-transfer or energy-transfer processes. The introduction of amino groups could increase the electron cloud density of Mg-APDA, thereby facilitating the electron-transfer or energy-transfer processes and then resulting in higher selectivity and sensitivity for luminescent detection. The improvements of luminescent detection performance by introducing amino group were also demonstrated in the literature.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel magnesium fluorescence MOF (Mg-APDA) was successfully synthesized based on a new amino-functionalized bridging ligand (H2APDA) and the environmentally friendly Mg­(II) ions. Mg-APDA shows a 3D framework with 1D hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites. The excellent fluorescent performance makes it a potential fluorescence sensing material to detect Fe­(III) ions with high selectivity. Besides, the low detection limits for DCN (150 ppb) and NFs (108 ppb for NZF, 126 ppb for NFT) also reveal the high sensitivity detection of Mg-APDA for trace levels of pesticide and antibiotics. The UV–vis absorption spectrum of Fe­(III) ions has a wide overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, indicating the existence of effective energy transfer and consequently leading to the decrease or quenching of the luminescence. The high quenching efficiencies for NFs and DCN may be ascribed to a combined effect from photoinduced electron transfer and resonance energy transfer. To our knowledge, this is the first example of amino-decorated Mg-LMOF as a multifunctional chemosensor used for the highly selective and sensitive detection of metal ions, pesticides, and antibiotics simultaneously.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a novel magnesium fluorescence MOF (Mg-APDA) was successfully synthesized based on a new amino-functionalized bridging ligand (H2APDA) and the environmentally friendly Mg(II) ions. Mg-APDA shows a 3D framework with 1D hexagonal channels decorated with Lewis-base amino sites. The excellent fluorescent performance makes it a potential fluorescence sensing material to detect Fe(III) ions with high selectivity. Besides, the low detection limits for DCN (150 ppb) and NFs (108 ppb for NZF, 126 ppb for NFT) also reveal the high sensitivity detection of Mg-APDA for trace levels of pesticide and antibiotics. The UV-vis absorption spectrum of Fe(III) ions has a wide overlap with the emission spectrum of Mg-APDA, indicating the existence of effective energy transfer and consequently leading to the decrease or quenching of the luminescence. The high quenching efficiencies for NFs and DCN may be ascribed to a combined effect from photoinduced electron transfer and resonance energy transfer. To our knowledge, this is the first example of amino-decorated Mg-LMOF as a multifunctional chemosensor used for the highly selective and sensitive detection of metal ions, pesticides, and antibiotics simultaneously.

cln_elements.content:
The synthetic procedures of the ligand, 4,4′-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)­dibenzoic acid (H2APDA), are described in detail in Section 1 of the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [Mg<sub>2</sub>(APDA)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·5DMA·5H<sub>2</sub>O (Mg-APDA)

A mixture of Mg­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.04 mmol) and H2APDA (0.01 mmol) was dissolved in DMA/ethanol/H2O mixed solvent (2.2 mL, v/v/v: 2/0.1/0.1), and then the solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1. Colorless crystals of Mg-APDA were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and then dried in air (yield: 58%, based on H2APDA). Anal. calcd (%): C, 53.88; H, 6.63; N, 9.75. Found (%): C, 53.82; H, 6.67; N, 9.78. IR (KBr, cm–1) (Figure S1): 3484 (w), 3394 (w), 1622 (s), 1549 (m), 1469 (w), 1406 (s), 1315 (w), 1184 (w), 1014 (m), 793 (m), 718 (w), 675 (w), 594 (w), 498 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Ligand (H2APDA)

The synthetic procedures of the ligand, 4,4'-(4-aminopyridine-3,5-diyl)dibenzoic acid (H2APDA), are described in detail in Section 1 of the Supporting Information.

Synthesis of [Mg2(APDA)2(H2O)3]⋅5DMA⋅5H2O (Mg-APDA)

A mixture of Mg(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.04 mmol) and H2APDA (0.01 mmol) was dissolved in DMA/ethanol/H2O mixed solvent (2.2 mL, v/v/v: 2/0.1/0.1), and then the solution was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and maintained at 140 °C for 2 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1. Colorless crystals of Mg-APDA were collected by filtration, washed with fresh DMA, and then dried in air (yield: 58%, based on H2APDA). Anal. calcd (%): C, 53.88; H, 6.63; N, 9.75. Found (%): C, 53.82; H, 6.67; N, 9.78. IR (KBr, cm-1) (Figure S1): 3484 (w), 3394 (w), 1622 (s), 1549 (m), 1469 (w), 1406 (s), 1315 (w), 1184 (w), 1014 (m), 793 (m), 718 (w), 675 (w), 594 (w), 498 (w).

cln_elements.content:
To get the information on the stability of Mg-APDA, TGA was conducted from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S2). The TGA curve shows a weight loss of 40.87% from 30 to 170 °C, which corresponds to the loss of free DMA and water molecules (calcd 40.66%), and the further weight loss corresponds to the slow decomposition of the framework. Besides, PXRD analysis was performed to determine the phase purity of Mg-APDA. As represented in Figure S3, the diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized Mg-APDA are highly consistent with the simulated PXRD patterns, indicative of the excellent phase purity. To determine the effect of fluorescence detections on the structural stability of the Mg-APDA framework, the samples after immersed in the DMF solution (1.0 mM) with different analytes (Fe­(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)) for 6 h were also analyzed by PXRD, as shown in Figure S4. It is seen that there is no significant difference in the PXRD patterns between the immersed sample and the original sample, which indicates that the basic Mg-APDA framework remains unchanged.

Photoluminescence Properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand and Mg-APDA were conducted at ambient temperature. As illustrated in Figure S5, the free ligand H2APDA shows a fluorescent emission band at 365 nm (λex = 339 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transition between the π-bonding orbital and π*-antibonding orbital. For comparison, Mg-APDA exhibits intense blue light emission at 384 nm (λex = 351 nm) with a 70.46% quantum yield. Compared to the free ligand, a significant red-shifted emission phenomenon is observed on Mg-APDA, and its fluorescent intensity dramatically increases. On account of the unique d0 electron configuration of Mg­(II) ions, it can be concluded that the fluorescence of Mg-APDA should originate from the APDA-centered emission.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability and PXRD Measurements

To get the information on the stability of Mg-APDA, TGA was conducted from 30 to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S2). The TGA curve shows a weight loss of 40.87% from 30 to 170 °C, which corresponds to the loss of free DMA and water molecules (calcd 40.66%), and the further weight loss corresponds to the slow decomposition of the framework. Besides, PXRD analysis was performed to determine the phase purity of Mg-APDA. As represented in Figure S3, the diffraction peaks of the as-synthesized Mg-APDA are highly consistent with the simulated PXRD patterns, indicative of the excellent phase purity. To determine the effect of fluorescence detections on the structural stability of the Mg-APDA framework, the samples after immersed in the DMF solution (1.0 mM) with different analytes (Fe(III), nitrofurazone (NZF), nitrofurantoin (NFT), and 2,6-dichloro-4-nitroaniline (DCN)) for 6 h were also analyzed by PXRD, as shown in Figure S4. It is seen that there is no significant difference in the PXRD patterns between the immersed sample and the original sample, which indicates that the basic Mg-APDA framework remains unchanged.

Photoluminescence Properties

The solid-state luminescence properties of the free ligand and Mg-APDA were conducted at ambient temperature. As illustrated in Figure S5, the free ligand H2APDA shows a fluorescent emission band at 365 nm (λex = 339 nm), which may be ascribed to the intraligand π → π* transition between the π-bonding orbital and π*-antibonding orbital. For comparison, Mg-APDA exhibits intense blue light emission at 384 nm (λex = 351 nm) with a 70.46% quantum yield. Compared to the free ligand, a significant red-shifted emission phenomenon is observed on Mg-APDA, and its fluorescent intensity dramatically increases. On account of the unique d0 electron configuration of Mg(II) ions, it can be concluded that the fluorescence of Mg-APDA should originate from the APDA-centered emission.

metadata.title:
A Novel Magnesium Metal–Organic Framework as
a Multiresponsive Luminescent Sensor for Fe(III) Ions, Pesticides,
and Antibiotics with High Selectivity and Sensitivity
